sect1.title: Introduction
sect1.para: &app; allows you to load the text from an ebook PDF file and restore a more natural flow to the story.
&app; supports in-line spell-checking, and keyboard shortcuts.

sect1.title: Getting Started
sect1.para:
You can start &app; in the following ways:
Applications menu
Choose Internet Drivel Journal Editor .
Command line
Type gpdftext, then press Return.

sect2.title: Editing an Existing ebook
sect2.para: &app; allows you to edit the text from the ebook PDF.

sect3.title: Edit a Recent Entry
sect3.para: &app; builds a list of the fifteen most-recent ebooks.

sect3.title: Editing any Existing Entry (LiveJournal only)
sect3.para: To edit any previously-posted journal entry, choose EditHistory from the menu bar. This will open a window with a calendar. Any bold dates in the calendar have journal entries associated with them. The controls on the calendar can be used to go back months or even years. Once you've selected the date the entry you'd like to modify was posted, a list of entries from that day will appear in the bottom of the window. Select the entry to modify and click Edit. Once you have completed your modifications, click Update to update the entry in your journal.

sect2.title: Working in the gPDFText Editor Window
sect2.para: The editor built into &app; includes inline spell-checking.

sect3.title: Spell Checking
sect3.para: To enable inline spell-checking, click ViewHighlight Spelling Errors in the menu bar. A wavy red line will appear underneath misspelled words. Right-clicking on the word will display a menu with a Spelling Suggestions submenu. Clicking on a displayed suggestion will insert it in place of the misspelled word.
Press the F7 key to quickly enable or disable the spell-checker.

sect1.title: About &app;
sect1.para: &app; was written by Neil Williams (linux@codehelp.co.uk). To find more information about &app;, please visit the gPDFText Wiki.
